content:
What does that mean for 2020?

MIDWESTERNERS grew used to presidential visits during the mid-term election campaigns. In the final two weeks of the campaign Donald Trump roused voters at rallies in Wisconsin, Illinois, Pennsylvania, Missouri (twice), Indiana (twice) and Ohio (twice). For the Democrats, Barack Obama paid regular visits, kicking off his post-White House return to public life in September with a feisty speech in downstate Illinois, before adding visits to Wisconsin, Indiana and, once again, Illinois.

They came for a pair of reasons. First, the region hosted several competitive races for House, Senate and Governor. In this off-year election, more than usual, national politics especially stirred up voters. The other reason, for those already looking ahead to the presidential race in 2020, is that the Midwest will again be influential as a battleground. Narrow victories for Mr Trump in Wisconsin, Michigan and Pennsylvania gave him with a path to the presidency in 2016. Mid-term results in these states are being studied closely for evidence that he might prove successful again.

What does the evidence suggest? Each party has something to cheer. Look at Senate results and the picture was undoubtedly brighter for Republicans. A Wisconsin Democrat, Tammy Baldwin, might have kept her potentially vulnerable seat with ease, as did senators in Ohio, Michigan and Minnesota. But Republicans gained in Indiana, Missouri and North Dakota, dashing Democrats’ hopes that Midwestern soybean farmers, for example, might turn against the Republicans. A worsening trade spat with China has disrupted agricultural markets and two more years of economic pain could produce a different outcome, but Democrats can’t bet on it.

In the House, Democrats had the better time. Of the 27 congressional seats the Democrats gained nationally, eleven were in the Midwest (depending how you define the region): three in Pennsylvania, two in each of Illinois, Iowa, Michigan and Minnesota, plus one in Kansas. Crucially, these were mostly seats gained in suburbs, not truly urban areas. The party still struggles to win outright rural support. It is finding ways to  appeal in semi-rural areas, which is a start, but the urban-rural split remains as stark as ever.

Democrats also picked up significantly in state legislature and governors’ races, buoyed by heavy spending. The Republicans are pleased they held on in Iowa and South Dakota despite rumours of vulnerability there. The most dramatic Democratic win was by Laura Kelly (pictured), who will be governor of usually solid-red Kansas. (She was helped along by an opponent whose ultra-Trumpism and over hostility to migrants perhaps makes this result a one-off).

Tony Evers, a mild-mannered former teacher also succeeded, by the thinnest of whiskers, in stopping Scott Walker from getting a third term as Republican governor in Wisconsin. Gretchen Whitmer picked up an open Governor seat in Michigan; while a billionaire, J.B. Pritzker, toppled a weak, moderate Republican in Illinois. Honours were shared in two other races—Democrats held on in Pennsylvania, while Republicans kept their man in Ohio. In Colorado, if the definition of the Midwest is stretched farther west, the Democrats produced the first gay man to be elected as governor.

In all, the Democrats probably feel happier with the outcome. Given the current cheerful economic climate (farming aside) in much of the region, Republican incumbents might have expected to get more credit from voters. Unemployment is generally low; wage growth is beginning to climb; and in Wisconsin, for example, Mr Walker had won a big investment in a factory by Foxconn, a Taiwanese manufacturer (though only by promising enormous subsidies that look all but impossible to justify). Instead many voters appeared to be moved by other issues, such as a wish for access to expanded Medicaid or for higher spending on schools or roads, or they reacted badly to Mr Trump’s vitriol against immigrants. In Illinois Mr Rauner looked hopelessly isolated. Some voters in suburbs, such as in Naperville, a formerly Republican area an hour west of Chicago, said they most wanted to send a message that they dislike Mr Trump.

Despite that, there is little evidence for the Democrats to conclude that the Midwest will be theirs in 2020. A high turnout appeared to help Democrats in particular. But they won different races across the regions because of a variety of candidates and different strategies that will be hard to repeat two years from now.

adj. 狭窄的；窄小的；勉强的；刚刚好的
v. 使窄小；变窄；缩小
n. 峡谷；(场所,物品等的)狭窄部分
网络 狭隘的
eg2: narrow streets
狭窄的街道
a narrow bed/doorway/shelf
狭窄的床╱门口╱架子
narrow shoulders/hips
窄小的肩头╱臀部
There was only a narrow gap between the bed and the wall.
床和墙之间只有一条窄缝。
the narrow confines of prison life
狱中生活的狭小天地
a narrow victory
险胜
He lost the race by the narrowest of margins .
他以极小的差距在赛跑中落败。
She was elected by a narrow majority .
她以微弱多数当选。
He had a narrow escape when his car skidded on the ice.
车在冰上打滑，他险些出事。
narrow interests
目光短浅的利益
She has a very narrow view of the world.
她对世界的认识是非常狭隘的。
The shop sells only a narrow range of goods.
这家商店商品的种类有限。
a narrow circle of friends
有限的交友圈子
I am using the word ‘education’ in the narrower sense.
我说的是较狭义的“教育”。
This is where the river narrows.
这条河就是在这里变窄的。
The gap between the two teams has narrowed to three points.
两队之间的差距缩小到三分了。
Her eyes narrowed(= almost closed) menacingly.
她咄咄逼人地瞇起眼睛。
He narrowed his eyes at her.
他向她挤了挤眼睛。
We need to try and narrow the health divide between rich and poor.
我们需要设法缩小穷人和富人之间的健康差距。

他们享受一切快乐的事。
The captain's cheerful laugh dispelled our fears.
船长愉快的笑声消除了我们的恐惧。
At the banquet we chin-chinned and tried to look .
在宴会上我们互相举杯祝酒，尽量表现出高兴的神情。

ex: adj. 国会的；会议的；议会的

这是奥巴马和国会领导人的第四轮谈判。

9月19号下午，在众议院发言人办公室里举行的一个会议上，我正是这样告诉国会领袖们的。

wp.Rockman Dash: 洛克人钢铁之心;中文硬盘版;洛克人Dash;洛克人危机

ex: n. 破折号；冲撞

vi. 猛冲；撞击
n. (Dash)人名；(英、印)达什；(蒙)达希
eg2: Although the hyphen does look quite a bit like a dash or minus sign, it is a punctuation mark.
尽管连字符看上去很像破折号或减号，但他还是一个符点符号而非数字符号。
You can indicate a class by surrounding it in square braces; within the braces, you can have both a set of characters and character ranges indicated with a .
可以通过将类括在方括号内来表明这是一个类；在括号中，可以有一组字符或者用破折号指定的字符范围。
He has both skill and .
他既有技巧， 又有闯劲。

wp.disrupt t: 使中断;弄乱;破坏;使分裂

ex: vt. 破坏；使瓦解；使分裂；使中断；使陷于混乱
adj. 分裂的，中断的；分散的
eg2: It also assumes that components to be deleted will not  the interoperability of remaining components with others.
同样，它也假定要删除的组件将不会破坏剩余组件之间的互操作性。
Those who  the free flow of information in our society or any other pose a threat to our economy, our government, and our civil society.
那些在我们国家或任何其他国家破坏信息自由流通的人对我们的经济、我们的政府和我们的公民社会构成了威胁。
In recent years, some groups have resorted to threats and even violence in efforts to disrupt important research.
近年来，一些团体为了达到破坏重要研究的目的而诉诸于威胁甚至暴力。

ex: n. （美）在州里的南部
adv. 在州的南部
adj. 在州的南部的

ex: adj. 活跃的；好争吵的；烦躁不安的；坚决而据理力争的
eg2: He's a feisty ultraconservative who has managed, seemingly on purpose, to make enemies of all the other casino owners, a pretty friendly group.
他是一个活跃而又超级保守的人，他成功地，也似乎是故意地把其他赌场大亨的敌人们变成了一个友好的小团体。
On the whole, it was more structured and less , a bit like the first debate.
总体来说，这个环节更有条理，大家更冷静一些，与第一场辩论有点相似。

wp.Happier life: 生活的更加快乐;幸福的生活;幸福一生的时间去;幸福生活的时间
wp.Be Happier: 比哈贝尔;会开心;更快乐;抱抱的

ex: adj. 更快乐的，更幸福的
adv. 绝望地；无望地；无可救药地

wp.hopelessly romantic: 无可救药地浪漫;无奈浪漫;无可救药的浪漫
wp.Hopelessly apathetic: 无可救药的麻木不仁;绝望地麻木;绝望麻木不仁

eg2: They were hopelessly deadlocked in almost total differences of opinion and outlook.
他们绝望地陷于意见和观点完全分歧的僵局之中。
Advocates of temping also argue that the traditional market for managers—and particularly for chief executives—is hopelessly inefficient.
临工倡导者也认为传统的经理市场，尤其是行政总裁，其效率是无可救药的低下。
While most people took that as a good thing, to me it was an indication almost of how hopelessly difficult the whole thing is going to be.
尽管大多数人都认为这是一件好事，但是对我来说，这更象是个表明整个事情将会是如何困难得令人绝望的迹象。

ex: n. 敌意；对抗；（对思想、计划或情形的）愤怒反对；战争行为
网络 敌对；敌对状态；敌视
eg2: feelings of hostility towards people from other backgrounds
对不同背景的人的敌视情绪
There was open hostility between the two schools.
这两所学校公开相互敌对。
public hostility to nuclear power
公众对核动力的愤然反对
the start/outbreak of hostilities between the two sides
双方之间敌对行为的爆发
a cessation of hostilities(= an end to fighting)
战争停止

ex: adj. 现任的；依靠的；负有职责的
n. 在职者；现任者；领圣俸者
eg2: Particularly if you have got an incumbent president and we no longer stick to the public financing, which was a result of the Watergate scandal.
特别是如果你有一个现任总统，同时我们也不再坚持使用公共资金作为竞选经费，那样的话就会发生水门事件那样的丑闻。
As several writers point out in this journal, this is the first election in 80 years with no incumbent president or vice president running for office.
诚如本期中的多位作者所指出的，这是美国80年来首次既无现任总统又无现任副总统参加竞选的选举。

wp.influential observation: 强影响点;观察值;有影响的观测值

ex: adj. 有影响的；有势力的
n. 有影响力的人物
eg2: Why were you  with them?
你为什么会对他们有影响呢？
His boss was rather influential in the government circles.
他的老板在政界还是颇有影响的。
I asked some of the most  and widely respected practitioners in UX what they consider to be the biggest misperceptions of what we do.
我请求一些在用户体验方面有影响和广受尊敬的专家，例举了一些在他们认为我们对用户体验最大的误解是什么。

ex: v. 孤立；将…剔出（以便看清和单独处理）；使（某物质、细胞等）分离
n. 【微】分离菌；隔离种群
网络 使孤立；使隔离；隔绝
eg2: Patients with the disease should be isolated.
这种病的患者应予以隔离。
He was immediately isolated from the other prisoners.
他被立刻与其他囚犯隔离开来。
This decision will isolate the country from the rest of Europe.
这一决定会使国家孤立于欧洲其他国家。
It is possible to isolate a number of factors that contributed to her downfall.
可以找出造成她垮台的一些因素。
Researchers are still trying to isolate the gene that causes this abnormality.
研究人员仍然在试图分离导致这种畸形的基因。

ex: n. 立法机关

务必按厂家的用法说明使用。

ex: adj. 完全的；彻底的；绝对的；公开的
adv. 公开地；直率地；毫无保留地；完全彻底
网络 彻底地；直率的；总冠军
eg2: an outright ban/rejection/victory
完全禁止；断然拒绝；彻底胜利
She was the outright winner.
她是绝对的优胜者。
No one party is expected to gain an outright majority.
没有任何政党可望获得绝对多数。
There was outright opposition to the plan.
该计划遭到公开直接反对。
Why don't you ask him outright if it's true?
你为什么不直截了当地问他那是否属实？
She couldn't help herself and she laughed outright.
她忍不住大笑起来。
Neither candidate won outright.
两个候选人谁也没干脆利落地获胜。
The group rejects outright any negotiations with the government.
这个团体断然拒绝与政府进行任何谈判。
Most of the crash victims were killed outright .
飞机坠毁的遇难者大都是当场死亡。
We had saved enough money to buy the house outright.
我们存了足够的钱，能一次付清款项买下这所房子。
